DOC.HEAD: Tanker Carrying Hazardous Chemicals Aground At Buffalo
Eds: New throughout with tanker freed; No pickup; Also moved on general news wires
DOC.TEXT: A tanker carrying 13.2 million pounds of hazardous chemicals ran aground Friday in Lake Erie, but there was no leakage and the ship was freed a few hours later by Coast Guard tugboats. The 428-foot tanker Kiisla, built and registered in Finland, was towed by two tugs to the Buffalo Port Authority for inspection. The accident tore a hole in the outer hull of the tanker, but the inner hull was not damaged, Petty Officer Ray Cramer said. The ship took on some water but did not leak any cargo, Cramer said. The Kiisla has an icebreaking hull and is a ``sturdy vessel,'' said Coast Guard Chief Warrant Officer Vern Williams in Buffalo. Petty Officer Ray Cramer said the tanker draws 21 feet of water, but neither he nor Williams knew how deep the bottom was where it went aground in the mostly ice-covered lake outside Buffalo harbor. The tanker was carrying 3,141 metric tons of xylene and 2,876 metric tons of toluene, or about 13.2 million pounds of the two industrial solvents, to Buffalo, Williams said. Authorities did not know where the cargo originated.
